definition: lit. don't sit under the eaves (where tiles may fall from the roof) (idiom); fig. keep out of danger
surname Zuo
to sit/to take a seat/to take (a bus, airplane etc)/to bear fruit/variant of 座[zuo4]
(negative prefix)/not/no
to hang (down)/droop/dangle/bend down/hand down/bequeath/nearly/almost/to approach

(main) hall/large room for a specific purpose/CL:間|间[jian1]/relationship between cousins etc on the paternal side of a family/of the same clan/classifier for classes, lectures etc/classifier for sets of furniture
lit. a wealthy person does not sit under the eaves (idiom); fig. a rich man does not expose himself to danger
pinyin: jia1 lei3 qian1 jin1 , zuo4 bu4 chui2 tang2

definition: one word worth a thousand in gold (idiom); valuable advice/words of enormous weight
to live in luxury/lit. to ride a solid carriage pulled by fat horses
lit. light as a goose feather, heavy as Mt Tai (idiom)/fig. of no consequence to one person, a matter of life or death to another
precarious as the morning dew (idiom); fig. ephemeral and precarious nature of human existence
person narrow-minded and shortsighted
has eyes but can't see (idiom); unable or unwilling to see the importance of sth/blind (to sth great)
clay ox, wooden horse (idiom); shape without substance/worthless object
if it's plowing, ask the laborer (idiom); when managing a matter, consult the appropriate specialist
sacrificing one's life generously (idiom); to sacrifice oneself fervently to the cause
lit. to wear one's coat inside out and carry firewood on one's back (idiom)/fig. to live a life of poverty and hard work/fig. to act stupidly

how? (emphatic question)
old variant of 愷|恺[kai3]/old variant of 凱|凯[kai3]
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
to correct in the evening a fault of the morning (idiom)/to quickly amend one's ways
